title: IFORS' Operational Research hall of fame Stafford Beer
abstract:
Innovative Operational Research practitioner, intellectual leader in the development of systems ideas, and founder of the field of management cybernetics.\ud
Born: September 25, 1926 in London, England.\ud
Died: August 23, 2002 in Toronto, Canada.\ud
Education: D.Sc., University of Sunderland,\ud
2000.\ud
Key positions: Production Controller and\ud
Head of OR Group, Samuel Fox (1949–1956);\ud
Head, Operational Research and Cybernetics,\ud
United Steel (1956–1961); Managing Director,\ud
SIGMA (1961–1966); Development Director,\ud
International Publishing Corporation (1966–\ud
1970); Consultant (1970–2002).\ud
Awards and Recognition: Silver Medal, Royal\ud
Swedish Academy for Engineering Sciences\ud
(1958); Lanchester Prize, Operations Research\ud
Society of America (1966); McCullough Plaque\ud
of the American Society for Cybernetics (1970);\ud
Norbert Weiner Gold Medal, World Organization\ud
of Systems and Cybernetics (1984); Lifetime\ud
Achievement Award, UK Systems Society\ud
(1999); Honorary degrees: Doctor of Laws,\ud
Concordia University, Montreal, Canada\ud
(1988); Doctor of Economic Sciences, University\ud
of St. Gallen, Switzerland (2000).\ud
Key OR roles: President, Operational Research\ud
Society (1970–1971); President, Society\ud
for General Systems Research (1971–1972);\ud
President, World Organization of Systems and\ud
Cybernetics (1970–the time of his death).\ud
Stafford Beer was one of the most remarkable figures that Operational Research (OR) in any country has produced. A charismatic, even flamboyant, character, he founded two major and pioneering OR groups; wrote some of the best books about the subject; and was a world leader in the development of systems ideas. He is widely acknowledged as the founder of the field of International Transactions in Operational Resarch
